comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: The propeller says "Garuda," which was a manufacturer in Berlin: www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200252... Outsourcing, I guess.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
70251312@N00
comment._content: Igor Sikorsky (1889-1972) came to America in 1919, and became a U. S. citizen in 1928. Wikipedia on Igor Sikorsky: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
This HAS to be a joke! The photographer is playing with perspective. If the distance between each pair of men is about 6 feet, the propeller would be around 36 feet long.  Sikorsky's giant Ilya Muromets bombers had large propellers, but they appear to be about 10 feet in diameter in most archival photos.  

There's definitely something funny going on here. Look closely at how the giant propeller is sitting on the sawhorses.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Agree with techno -- notice the four guys on the far end are standing on an inclined plane, which is monkeying with the perspective. Also the propeller itself has a weird outline, as if cut and pasted onto the photograph. On the other hand, the Germans built a plane with a 23-ft Garuda propeller ( www.markslists.net/history/germangiants/index.html ) . If the guy on the near end is about 6-ft tall, this propeller might go 23 ft.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
Thanks for the link, rjones0856! 

Another possiblity is that this gigantic propeller is real but it was fabricated entirely for display, i.e. to show what the company was capable of building. It may have been shown at an air meet or a trade fair. Or maybe it was presented to Sikorsky as a gift for bringing so much business to Garuda.
